elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">Reported herein are two porous interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks tuned by the length of organic linker. Shorter BDC linker and [Cd(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] building blocks in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> generate a rare 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating qtz network. But longer NDC linker in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> produces a self-penetrated 8-connected bcu framework with [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] SBUs. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both show selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption and significantly, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits the highest water vapor uptake performance (281<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and P/P<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.95) among all the interpenetrated MOFs.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Reported herein are two porous interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks tuned by the length of organic linker. Shorter BDC linker and [Cd(COO)4] building blocks in 1 generate a rare 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating qtz network. But longer NDC linker in 2 produces a self-penetrated 8-connected bcu framework with [Cd3(COO)8] SBUs. 1 and 2 both show selective CO2 adsorption and significantly, 2 exhibits the highest water vapor uptake performance (281cm3·g−1 at 298K and P/P0
=0.95) among all the interpenetrated MOFs.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">The bulk of linkers introduced to two 3D interpenetrated porous Cd-MOFs exhibiting 2-fold interpenetrated <ce:italic>qtz</ce:italic> and self-penetrated <ce:italic>bcu</ce:italic> nets, which have selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake and highest water vapor uptake performance among all the interpenetrated MOFs.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:link id="lk0020" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
The bulk of linkers introduced to two 3D interpenetrated porous Cd-MOFs exhibiting 2-fold interpenetrated qtz and self-penetrated bcu nets, which have selective CO2 uptake and highest water vapor uptake performance among all the interpenetrated MOFs.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:link id="lk0020" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">3D interpenetrated porous Cd-MOFs</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">4-Connected Cd(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and 8-connected Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> SBUs</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">2-Fold interpenetrated <ce:italic>qtz</ce:italic> and self-penetrated <ce:italic>bcu</ce:italic> nets</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0020">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptakes and high water vapor adsorption performance.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights



•
3D interpenetrated porous Cd-MOFs


•
4-Connected Cd(COO)4 and 8-connected Cd3(COO)8 SBUs


•
2-Fold interpenetrated qtz and self-penetrated bcu nets


•
Selective CO2 uptakes and high water vapor adsorption performance.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">3D interpenetrated porous Cd-MOFs</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">4-Connected Cd(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and 8-connected Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> SBUs</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">2-Fold interpenetrated <ce:italic>qtz</ce:italic> and self-penetrated <ce:italic>bcu</ce:italic> nets</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptakes and high water vapor adsorption performance.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous hybrid organic–inorganic materials consisting of metal cations or metal oxide clusters bridged by organic linker molecules . In the past two decades, the rational design and construction of MOFs have attracted fast growing attentions due to their intriguing structural architectures and potential applications as functional materials .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
3D interpenetrated porous Cd-MOFs
4-Connected Cd(COO)4 and 8-connected Cd3(COO)8 SBUs
2-Fold interpenetrated qtz and self-penetrated bcu nets
Selective CO2 uptakes and high water vapor adsorption performance.
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous hybrid organic–inorganic materials consisting of metal cations or metal oxide clusters bridged by organic linker molecules . In the past two decades, the rational design and construction of MOFs have attracted fast growing attentions due to their intriguing structural architectures and potential applications as functional materials .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Among a lot of structure features of MOFs, porosity is the most important one and plays a significant role in their functional properties . Up to now, much work has been devoted to this field and sufficient experimental data were accumulated, which allows chemists to rationally assemble the targeted structures through effective synthetic tactics including ‘node-and-spacer’ and ‘secondary building units (SBUs)’.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Among a lot of structure features of MOFs, porosity is the most important one and plays a significant role in their functional properties . Up to now, much work has been devoted to this field and sufficient experimental data were accumulated, which allows chemists to rationally assemble the targeted structures through effective synthetic tactics including ‘node-and-spacer’ and ‘secondary building units (SBUs)’.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">However, it is still a challenging task to perfectly design and modulate the specific crystal packing with the expected structures and properties because of many factors that can affect the growth of MOF crystals . In this aspect, the structural characteristics of the organic linkers have been verified as an efficient strategy toward the augmentation of the pore size or surface area of open MOFs .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: However, it is still a challenging task to perfectly design and modulate the specific crystal packing with the expected structures and properties because of many factors that can affect the growth of MOF crystals . In this aspect, the structural characteristics of the organic linkers have been verified as an efficient strategy toward the augmentation of the pore size or surface area of open MOFs .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">On the other hand, structural interpenetration is of great interests in the development of porous MOFs because of the degree of interpenetration can not only effectively adjust the pore architecture of MOFs, but also may enhance the stability of frameworks through filling of void space . The structural interpenetration is closely related to gas adsorption properties of MOFs. Generally speaking, interpenetration can be used for practical advantage if one desires a MOF with small pore sizes, which could be beneficial to selective gas uptakes. However, to our knowledge, the phenomenon of interpenetration in MOFs for selective gas uptake is far less well studied experimentally since the vast majority of MOFs are non-interpenetrated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, structural interpenetration is of great interests in the development of porous MOFs because of the degree of interpenetration can not only effectively adjust the pore architecture of MOFs, but also may enhance the stability of frameworks through filling of void space . The structural interpenetration is closely related to gas adsorption properties of MOFs. Generally speaking, interpenetration can be used for practical advantage if one desires a MOF with small pore sizes, which could be beneficial to selective gas uptakes. However, to our knowledge, the phenomenon of interpenetration in MOFs for selective gas uptake is far less well studied experimentally since the vast majority of MOFs are non-interpenetrated.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">More recently, we report a 3-fold self-interpenetrated Zn-carboxylate MOF, which presents an unprecedented 1D channel partition <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> interpenetration into polyhedral cages . The unique structural feature contributed to not only the highest CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake capacity but also strongest CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> affinity among the interpenetrated MOFs. As an extension of this work, we demonstrated herein two interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks effectively tuned by the length of organic linkers, namely, {[(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Cd(BDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(NDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (BDC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>terephthalic acid, NDC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid). As we expected, interpenetrated MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both have small pore sizes, and show selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption. Significantly, MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits the highest water vapor uptake performance (281<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>) at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.95 among the interpenetrated MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
More recently, we report a 3-fold self-interpenetrated Zn-carboxylate MOF, which presents an unprecedented 1D channel partition via interpenetration into polyhedral cages . The unique structural feature contributed to not only the highest CO2 uptake capacity but also strongest CO2 affinity among the interpenetrated MOFs. As an extension of this work, we demonstrated herein two interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks effectively tuned by the length of organic linkers, namely, {[(CH3)2NH2]2[Cd(BDC)2]}
n
 (1) and {[(CH3)2NH2]2[Cd3(NDC)4]}
n
 (2) (BDC=terephthalic acid, NDC=2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid). As we expected, interpenetrated MOFs 1 and 2 both have small pore sizes, and show selective CO2 adsorption. Significantly, MOF 2 exhibits the highest water vapor uptake performance (281cm3·g−1) at 298K and P/P
0
=0.95 among the interpenetrated MOFs.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Colorless hexagonal prism crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were got in pure phase under the hydrothermal reaction of Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and the most common ditopic carboxylic acid linker (BDC) . Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that MOF <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating <ce:italic>qtz</ce:italic> network crystallizing in the hexagonal <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>6(2)22 space group . The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains part of a Cd atom on a site with crystallographic 222 symmetry and one half of a BDC ligand lying about a twofold axis. Each Cd center adopts triangulated dodecahedral geometries by the chelation of four carboxylate groups from four BDC anions (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cd–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.352(6)–2.476(7) Å and the O–Cd–O bond angles range from 52.1(2) to 165.8(4)°. If the carboxylate groups are considered as connecting points, carbon atoms around the Cd centers in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> will show a highly distorted pseudo-tetrahedral geometry with the angles of C–Cd–C are 89.5(3), 100.8(4), and 145.2(3)°. Each Cd center connects to the other Cd centers by linear BDC bridges to produce a quartz network (<ce:italic>qtz</ce:italic>) (b). Twofold interpenetration is observed in the structure of MOF <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, in which the pseudotetrahedron centers in one net occupy on the center of the 6-ring in another network, and the four arms of tetrahedron are interpenetrated through 6-ring each other in the up–down–up–down form (c,d). 1D channel exists along the <ce:italic>c-</ce:italic>axis direction, which is occupied by the disordered [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> to balance the charge of anionic Cd-BDC framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Colorless hexagonal prism crystals of 1 were got in pure phase under the hydrothermal reaction of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O and the most common ditopic carboxylic acid linker (BDC) . Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that MOF 1 is a 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating qtz network crystallizing in the hexagonal P6(2)22 space group . The asymmetric unit of 1 contains part of a Cd atom on a site with crystallographic 222 symmetry and one half of a BDC ligand lying about a twofold axis. Each Cd center adopts triangulated dodecahedral geometries by the chelation of four carboxylate groups from four BDC anions (a). The Cd–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.352(6)–2.476(7) Å and the O–Cd–O bond angles range from 52.1(2) to 165.8(4)°. If the carboxylate groups are considered as connecting points, carbon atoms around the Cd centers in 1 will show a highly distorted pseudo-tetrahedral geometry with the angles of C–Cd–C are 89.5(3), 100.8(4), and 145.2(3)°. Each Cd center connects to the other Cd centers by linear BDC bridges to produce a quartz network (qtz) (b). Twofold interpenetration is observed in the structure of MOF 1, in which the pseudotetrahedron centers in one net occupy on the center of the 6-ring in another network, and the four arms of tetrahedron are interpenetrated through 6-ring each other in the up–down–up–down form (c,d). 1D channel exists along the c-axis direction, which is occupied by the disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ to balance the charge of anionic Cd-BDC framework of 1.

other properties: Cd–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.352(6)–2.476(7) Å
O–Cd–O bond angles range from 52.1(2) to 165.8(4)°
1D channel exists along the c-axis direction
Disordered [(CH3)2NH2]+ to balance the charge of anionic Cd-BDC framework

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Under the similar reaction conditions, the utilization of longer ditopic carboxylic acid linker (NDC) instead of BDC led to the formation of yellow block crystals of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study shows that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic <ce:italic>Fdd</ce:italic>2 space group . The asymmetric unit contains three unique Cd(II) atoms and four independent NDC ligands. As depicted in a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, three Cd atoms all exhibit distorted octahedral configuration generated by six oxygen atoms from different NDC ligands. The Cd–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.187(7)–2.528(7) Å and the O–Cd–O bond angles range from 52.6(3) to 179.4(4)°. Three independent Cd atoms are bridged by six carboxylate groups from six different NDC ligands to form a linear trinuclear cluster with Cd3 as the symmetrical center. Cd1 and Cd2 further coordinate to one terminal chelating carboxlate group from another NDC. Overall, three Cd atoms link eight carbloxlate groups to give a [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> SBU. The Cd1–Cd3 and Cd2–Cd3 separations are of 3.4831(9) Å and 3.4658(10) Å, respectively. The trinuclear cluster and NDC ligands link each other to form the 3D porous framework of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (b). 1D irregular small channel is observed along the <ce:italic>c-</ce:italic>axis direction and occupied by the charge-balanced [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>. Furthermore, the [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> SBU and NDC ligands can be regarded as 8-connected node and linker as depicted in c, which led an 8-connected net with a point symbol of {4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>}. However, it should be pointed out that the 8-connected net of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is different from the common <ce:italic>bcu</ce:italic> net, which exhibits a self-penetration as shown in d. To the best of our knowledge, this kind of self-penetrating <ce:italic>bcu</ce:italic> net is rarely reported up to date. The only example reported by Wang  had a 4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>·5·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> topology with the four-membered ring is penetrated, but in the network of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, it is the six-membered ring. Clearly, the utilization of longer NDC linker effectively led to the transformation of mononuclear [Cd(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] to trinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> SBU, which further introduced the formation of 8-connected <ce:italic>bcu</ce:italic> net of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> instead of 4-connected <ce:italic>qtz</ce:italic> net of MOF <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Under the similar reaction conditions, the utilization of longer ditopic carboxylic acid linker (NDC) instead of BDC led to the formation of yellow block crystals of MOF 2
. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study shows that compound 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Fdd2 space group . The asymmetric unit contains three unique Cd(II) atoms and four independent NDC ligands. As depicted in a, three Cd atoms all exhibit distorted octahedral configuration generated by six oxygen atoms from different NDC ligands. The Cd–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.187(7)–2.528(7) Å and the O–Cd–O bond angles range from 52.6(3) to 179.4(4)°. Three independent Cd atoms are bridged by six carboxylate groups from six different NDC ligands to form a linear trinuclear cluster with Cd3 as the symmetrical center. Cd1 and Cd2 further coordinate to one terminal chelating carboxlate group from another NDC. Overall, three Cd atoms link eight carbloxlate groups to give a [Cd3(COO)8]2− SBU. The Cd1–Cd3 and Cd2–Cd3 separations are of 3.4831(9) Å and 3.4658(10) Å, respectively. The trinuclear cluster and NDC ligands link each other to form the 3D porous framework of MOF 2 (b). 1D irregular small channel is observed along the c-axis direction and occupied by the charge-balanced [(CH3)2NH2]+. Furthermore, the [Cd3(COO)8]2− SBU and NDC ligands can be regarded as 8-connected node and linker as depicted in c, which led an 8-connected net with a point symbol of {424·64}. However, it should be pointed out that the 8-connected net of MOF 2 is different from the common bcu net, which exhibits a self-penetration as shown in d. To the best of our knowledge, this kind of self-penetrating bcu net is rarely reported up to date. The only example reported by Wang  had a 424·5·63 topology with the four-membered ring is penetrated, but in the network of 2, it is the six-membered ring. Clearly, the utilization of longer NDC linker effectively led to the transformation of mononuclear [Cd(COO)4] to trinuclear [Cd3(COO)8]2− SBU, which further introduced the formation of 8-connected bcu net of MOF 2 instead of 4-connected qtz net of MOF 1.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Powder X-ray diffraction study indicates that MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both are phase-pure (Fig. S1). The photoluminescent properties of MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, BDC and NDC in the solid state at room temperature are depicted in Fig. S2. Upon excitation at 275<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> produced blue emissions at 410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 422<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. These fluorescence emissions should be assigned as the intraligand transition due to the similarity to the emissions of pure organic ligand, as well as the d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration of Cd(II).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray diffraction study indicates that MOFs 1 and 2 both are phase-pure (Fig. S1). The photoluminescent properties of MOFs 1, 2, BDC and NDC in the solid state at room temperature are depicted in Fig. S2. Upon excitation at 275nm, MOFs 1 and 2 produced blue emissions at 410nm and 422nm, respectively. These fluorescence emissions should be assigned as the intraligand transition due to the similarity to the emissions of pure organic ligand, as well as the d10 configuration of Cd(II).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Notably, as mentioned above, penetrated Cd-carboxylate frameworks <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both possess 1D channel along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-direction. PLATON calculations show that they have 61.8% and 48.6%, respectively, potential guest-accessible volumes. These prominent structure features provoke us to study their porosity. However, the N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sorption isotherms at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K indicate negligible uptakes for the MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> activated at 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is probably due to their small pore sizes introduced by the interpenetration and also blocked by the charge-balanced cations. It should be pointed out similar N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake results had also been found in an iso-structure of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> obtained in DMF solvent . Furthermore, the porosity of these two MOFs was supported by the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption at 195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (Fig. S3a). The corresponding BET surface area is 372<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 154<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. It should be noted that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a pressure-dependent, stepwise CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption–desorption isotherms at 195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which further support the dynamic twofold interpenetrating frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Notably, as mentioned above, penetrated Cd-carboxylate frameworks 1 and 2 both possess 1D channel along c-direction. PLATON calculations show that they have 61.8% and 48.6%, respectively, potential guest-accessible volumes. These prominent structure features provoke us to study their porosity. However, the N2 sorption isotherms at 77K indicate negligible uptakes for the MOFs 1 and 2 activated at 80°C, which is probably due to their small pore sizes introduced by the interpenetration and also blocked by the charge-balanced cations. It should be pointed out similar N2 uptake results had also been found in an iso-structure of MOF 2 obtained in DMF solvent . Furthermore, the porosity of these two MOFs was supported by the CO2 adsorption at 195K (Fig. S3a). The corresponding BET surface area is 372m2
g−1 and 154m2
g−1 for 1 and 2, respectively. It should be noted that compound 1 exhibits a pressure-dependent, stepwise CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at 195K, which further support the dynamic twofold interpenetrating frameworks.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The low-pressure CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Under 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bar, the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptakes at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K reach 42<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (1.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, 8.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%) for MOF <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (1.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, 4.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%) for MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). At 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bar, MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can absorb CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> of 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (1.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, 4.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%) and 13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (0.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, 2.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%). Although such CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption capacity is not high, these values still outperform many previously reported interpenetrated MOFs such as SNU-71 , YO-MOF  and so on. Compared to the no-interpenetrated MOFs, the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption capacity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is also higher than a lot of famous MOFs such as ZIF-8 , MOF-2 , SNU-31 , and ZIF-100  at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm. Clearly, take the negligible N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption into account, interpenetrated porous MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit dramatically selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake performance, which may be due to the small pore size introduced by interpenetration and the charged frameworks of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The low-pressure CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at 273K and 298K. Under 1bar, the CO2 uptakes at 273K reach 42cm3·g−1 (1.9mmol·g−1, 8.3wt.%) for MOF 1, and 24cm3·g−1 (1.1mmol·g−1, 4.7wt.%) for MOF 2 (a). At 298K and 1bar, MOFs 1 and 2 can absorb CO2 of 25cm3·g−1 (1.1mmol·g−1, 4.9wt.%) and 13cm3·g−1 (0.6mmol·g−1, 2.6wt.%). Although such CO2 adsorption capacity is not high, these values still outperform many previously reported interpenetrated MOFs such as SNU-71 , YO-MOF  and so on. Compared to the no-interpenetrated MOFs, the CO2 adsorption capacity of 1 is also higher than a lot of famous MOFs such as ZIF-8 , MOF-2 , SNU-31 , and ZIF-100  at 298K and 1atm. Clearly, take the negligible N2 adsorption into account, interpenetrated porous MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit dramatically selective CO2 uptake performance, which may be due to the small pore size introduced by interpenetration and the charged frameworks of 1 and 2.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">To further understand the above adsorption properties, the isosteric heat (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>st</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>) of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption was calculated using the experimental isotherm data at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (Fig. S3(b)). The <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>st</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> value of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is similar to those of some classical porous materials. The high initial <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>st</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can be mainly ascribed to the strong interactions between the charged framework and CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules. Then, the <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>st</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> falls to 17.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ·mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at loadings of 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, but increases up to 21.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ·mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at maximum loadings, which was attributed to increasing CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> interactions. For MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, its value at zero coverage is estimated to be about 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ·mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and increases slowly with increasing CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> loading. Finally, the value got to about 21<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ·mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. It is noted that these <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">st</ce:inf> values are comparable to a lot of famous MOFs such as CuBTTri , MOF-253 , and MAF-26  even though no open-metal sites and Lewis base sites exist in the framework of MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
To further understand the above adsorption properties, the isosteric heat (Q

st
) of CO2 adsorption was calculated using the experimental isotherm data at 273K and 298K (Fig. S3(b)). The Q

st
 value of complex 1 is similar to those of some classical porous materials. The high initial Q

st
 of CO2 can be mainly ascribed to the strong interactions between the charged framework and CO2 molecules. Then, the Q

st
 of CO2 falls to 17.5kJ·mol−1 at loadings of 0.1mmol·g−1, but increases up to 21.8kJ·mol−1 at maximum loadings, which was attributed to increasing CO2–CO2 interactions. For MOF 2, its value at zero coverage is estimated to be about 10kJ·mol−1 and increases slowly with increasing CO2 loading. Finally, the value got to about 21kJ·mol−1. It is noted that these Q
st values are comparable to a lot of famous MOFs such as CuBTTri , MOF-253 , and MAF-26  even though no open-metal sites and Lewis base sites exist in the framework of MOFs 1 and 2.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The adsorption of water vapor by porous solids is important for many applications, such as dehumidification, thermal batteries, and requiring capture and release of water. More recently, MOFs have been demonstrated to be promising water vapor adsorption materials . Herein, we further show that high and steep water vapor uptake at low relative pressure can be achieved by our interpenetrated Cd-NDC MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The water vapor adsorption isotherm of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is shown in b. Notably, the maximum water uptake at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K reaches 281<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> under <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.95 (where <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> is the vapor pressure at saturation). The maximum water uptake of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is comparable to the values of Basolite A100  and another cadmium(II) MOF  reported by D. F. Li, which are 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 249<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, respectively, Significantly, this value is much higher than a lot of MOF material, including CAU-10 functionalised by –NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and –OCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> groups , DUT-84 (Zr) , and Fe-MOFs reported by Tapas Kumar Maji . To the best of our knowledge, the water vapor adsorption capacity of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K outperforms all previously reported interpenetrated MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The adsorption of water vapor by porous solids is important for many applications, such as dehumidification, thermal batteries, and requiring capture and release of water. More recently, MOFs have been demonstrated to be promising water vapor adsorption materials . Herein, we further show that high and steep water vapor uptake at low relative pressure can be achieved by our interpenetrated Cd-NDC MOF 2. The water vapor adsorption isotherm of compound 2 is shown in b. Notably, the maximum water uptake at 298K reaches 281cm3·g−1 under P/P
0
=0.95 (where P
0 is the vapor pressure at saturation). The maximum water uptake of MOF 2 is comparable to the values of Basolite A100  and another cadmium(II) MOF  reported by D. F. Li, which are 250cm3·g−1 and 249cm3·g−1, respectively, Significantly, this value is much higher than a lot of MOF material, including CAU-10 functionalised by –NO2, −NH2, −CH3 and –OCH3 groups , DUT-84 (Zr) , and Fe-MOFs reported by Tapas Kumar Maji . To the best of our knowledge, the water vapor adsorption capacity of MOF 2 at 298K outperforms all previously reported interpenetrated MOFs.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">In conclusion, we demonstrated that the regulation of the bulk of linkers can lead to two 3D interpenetrated porous Cd-MOFs exhibiting 2-fold interpenetrated <ce:italic>qtz and</ce:italic> self-penetrated <ce:italic>bcu</ce:italic> nets. The small pore size introduced by interpenetration and charged frameworks contribute a dramatically selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake. In particular, Cd-NDC MOF shows the highest water vapor uptake performance among all the interpenetrated MOFs. Further exploration of interpenetrated porous frameworks with selective adsorption ability is ongoing.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we demonstrated that the regulation of the bulk of linkers can lead to two 3D interpenetrated porous Cd-MOFs exhibiting 2-fold interpenetrated qtz and self-penetrated bcu nets. The small pore size introduced by interpenetration and charged frameworks contribute a dramatically selective CO2 uptake. In particular, Cd-NDC MOF shows the highest water vapor uptake performance among all the interpenetrated MOFs. Further exploration of interpenetrated porous frameworks with selective adsorption ability is ongoing.

Supplementary material
Detailed experimental and crystallographic data, figures showing structural details, FT-IR spectra, XRD patterns and TGA curve have been included (CCDC 1054770 and 1054768). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2015.10.004.

metadata.title: Porous Cd-carboxylate frameworks tuned by the bulk of linker: Interpenetrated nets, selective CO2 uptakes and high water vapor adsorption
